By Julia Harte
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A criminal justice bill awaiting a vote by the U.S. Senate would reduce federal prison costs by $722 million over the next 10 years by releasing thousands of federal prisoners early
column2: congressional forecasters said on Wednesday.Federal benefits received by the newly released prisoners would increase direct spending by $251 million and reduce revenues by $8 million over the same period
column3: according to the estimate by the U.S. Congressional Budget Office.The new savings estimate buoyed supporters of the bipartisan measure to lower mandatory minimum sentences for some non-violent federal drug offenders
column4: which is central to President Barack Obama's efforts to overhaul the country's federal criminal justice system and reduce prison overcrowding. ""We have an obligation to change the way we think about incarceration
column5: and today's CBO report shows that we have a fiscal obligation as well
column6: said the bill's co-authors
column7: U.S. senators Charles Grassley
column8: a Republican from Iowa
column9: and Richard Durbin

column1: The bill was revised last month to exclude prisoners convicted of violent crimes in an effort to garner more support among conservatives. Still
column2: its prospects for moving to a full Senate vote remain unclear. Some key Republican senators are reluctant to support the bill until it includes changes to ""mens rea"" laws that govern criminal intent.

column1: Parallel sentencing reforms await a floor vote in the U.S. House of Representatives.A White House study last month found that current sentencing and incarceration policies strain state budgets
column2: take people out of the work force and pull families apart more than they reduce crime or boost the U.S. economy.

WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate on Tuesday cleared the way for approval of $1.1 billion in immediate funds to battle the Zika virus that is linked to birth defects
column2: well above what is in legislation pending in the House of Representatives.By a vote of 68-29
column3: senators limited debate on the measure
column4: paving the way for likely Senate approval this week. Two other funding approaches failed to get enough support to advance in the Senate.Meanwhile
column5: the White House threatened to veto a $622.1 million Zika bill poised to pass the House of Representatives later this week
column6: saying it was ""woefully inadequate.""Unlike the Senate legislation
column7: the House bill also requires that the $622.1 million be fully offset with spending cuts elsewhere.Many conservative Republicans in the House refuse to approve Zika funds that would add to federal budget deficits
column8: while Democrats and some Senate Republicans favor treating the problem as an emergency that would not have to be financed with spending cuts.Republican Senator Roy Blunt from Missouri told reporters that the Senate measure ""trimmed this package back (from Obama's request) to what really addresses the emergency at the time.""

column1: Democratic Senator Patty Murray from Washington
column2: who crafted the legislation with Blunt
column3: added
column4: ""We are going to need to keep the pressure on House Republicans to set aside their partisan bill and actually get the administration the emergency resources they need.""It was unclear how long it might take the Senate and House to work out their differences once they pass their respective bills.U.S. health officials have concluded that Zika infections in pregnant women can cause microcephaly
column5: a birth defect marked by small head size that can lead to severe developmental problems in babies. The World Health Organization has said there is strong scientific consensus that Zika can also cause Guillain-Barre
column6: a rare neurological syndrome that causes temporary paralysis in adults.

column1: Last year
column2: Brazil began detecting an increase in microcephaly and the virus has been spreading rapidly in the Americas
column3: with new cases now being reported in warm climates in southern U.S. states including Florida.House Republicans argue their $622.1 million bill
column4: when coupled with $589 million the Obama administration already shifted to Zika from unused funds to battle Ebola
column5: would provide enough money through Sept. 30
column6: the end of this fiscal year.

By Daniel Wiessner
The Obama administration on Tuesday unveiled the final version of a long-awaited and controversial rule to extend overtime pay to 4.2 million U.S. workers
column2: which marks one of the administration's most significant moves to address stagnant wages. The rule
column3: which has drawn intense criticism from business groups and Republicans
column4: doubles the maximum annual income a salaried worker can earn and still be automatically eligible for overtime pay from $23
column6: 476 and requires that threshold to be updated every three years. It takes effect Dec. 1.Officials said many workers will earn more money
column7: an estimated total of $12 billion over the next decade
column8: while others will work fewer hours for the same pay.""More than 4 million workers are either going to be paid more or get time back to raise their family
column9: go to school ... or retrain to get a better job
column10: Vice President Joe Biden said during a phone call with reporters on Tuesday.The rule will likely touch nearly every sector of the U.S. economy but is expected to have the greatest impact on nonprofit groups
column13: which have many management workers whose salaries are below the new threshold.

column1: Business groups
column2: which lobbied heavily against the changes
column3: say companies will be forced to cut wages and hours and may slow hiring.The Obama administration and supporters of the new rule say the $23
column4: 660 threshold allowed companies to hold down labor costs by requiring workers with relatively low incomes to work well over 40 hours per week without additional pay.

column1: The rule will likely face legal challenges

column5: but the last-minute change to lower it
column6: which was widely expected
column7: did little to appease critics. Any federal standard above the $35

column9: which has a high cost of living
column10: will inhibit economic growth in more rural states in the South and Midwest
column12: a Washington D.C. lawyer who works with the U.S. Chamber of Commerce
column13: said on Tuesday before the final rule was announced.

WASHINGTON Democrat candidates Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders each picked up primary wins on Tuesday in yet another demonstration of how divided the party is in the drawn-out national race to win the nomination for November's general election.Clinton narrowly defeated Sanders in Kentucky
column2: a state where she was not expected to win. Sanders bested her in Oregon

column8: including California

column17: in an interview with Megyn Kelly that aired on Fox News Tuesday night
column18: said he did have regrets about his actions during the Republican primary process.""I could have used different language in a couple of instances
column19: but overall I'm happy with the outcome

column1: Sanders supporters became angry when Nevada state party officials chose to end their convention and block efforts to award the U.S. senator from Vermont more delegates than he initially won in the February caucus. Clinton won the caucus.

The Nevada incident was a warning about the potential for fireworks at July's Democratic National Convention in Philadelphia.Clinton's campaign continued to express confidence that she would be able to unify the party.""Hillary Clinton is grateful to the thousands of Nevadans who came out to participate in the caucuses and convention process
column2: Clinton campaign manager Robby Mook said.""She believes every voice should be heard and no one should be intimidated

column6: unhappy about being blocked in a rules vote that was part of the effort to help the senator win more delegates to the national convention. Others drew chalk graffiti on a party building
column7: while the state's party chairwoman has been receiving death threats.

column1: Sanders framed Nevada's incident as a warning.""If the Democratic Party is to be successful in November

column4: arguing that state party Chairwoman Roberta Lange did not allow a headcount on a disputed rules change. He also argued that 64 delegates to the state convention were not given a hearing before being ruled ineligible.THREATS OF VIOLENCE

column5: Lange said on MSNBC. ""Threats to my family
column6: to my grandson
column7: to my husband. Sanders' continued presence in the race is prompting concerns among Clinton allies that he will damage her ability to take on Trump and hurt her in the fall. But Sanders supporters shrug off that worry
column8: arguing that Trump is such a flawed candidate that Clinton will easily dispatch with him if she faces him in the Nov. 8 election.Clinton's camp seems to agree. ""Ultimately

By Amanda Becker and Valerie Volcovici
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential front-runner Hillary Clinton begins a two-day tour on Monday through rural

column3: anti-trade message has resonated with economically distressed voters. Clinton

column2: who helped broker the deal
column3: said this month that the U.S. election was critical to its future. ""If a climate change denier was to be elected
column4: it would threaten dramatically global action against climate disruption
column5: he said.Trump has said that he believes global warming is a concept that was invented by China to hurt the competitiveness of U.S. business. One of his energy policy advisers is a climate change skeptic
column6: U.S. Congressman Kevin Cramer of North Dakota.Hillary Clinton
column7: the leading Democratic contender for the White House
column8: has advocated shifting the country to 50 percent clean energy by 2030.Trump's comment drew fire from environmental advocates.

column1: This is another example of Trump's dangerous lack of judgment and the very real impacts it could have for all of us
column2: said Gene Karpinski
column3: president of the U.S.-based environmental group League of Conservation Voters. ""Trump's denunciation of the Paris climate accord is not only short sighted
column4: but would be terribly costly for America and our ability to lead the world. We cannot go backwards on this important step towards a clean energy economy that benefits all our families
column5: billionaire environmental financier Tom Steyer said in a statement.The Paris agreement has an article built into it meant to protect countries in the accord in the event that a new government comes in and wants to dismantle it. The clause says any nation wanting to withdraw will first have to wait four years.U.S. chief climate envoy Jonathan Pershing said last week that regardless of the outcome of the U.S. election
column6: other countries were likely to be bound by the pact. (Reporting by Emily Flitter and Steve Holland; Additional reporting by Valerie Volcovici; Writing by Richard Valdmanis; Editing by Ross Colvin and Tiffany Wu)"	['Cramer'

column1: NEW YORK - Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump told Reuters in a wide-ranging interview on Tuesday that he would be willing to talk to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un to try to stop Pyongyang's nuclear program.He also called for a renegotiation of the Paris climate accord and said he would dismantle most of the Dodd-Frank financial regulations if he is elected president.Here are excerpts of the interview.NORTH KOREA
On speaking to Kim Jong Un:""I would speak to him. I would have no problem speaking to him. At the same time
column2: I would put a lot of pressure on China because economically we have tremendous power over China. People don't realize that. They are extracting vast billions of dollars out of our country. Billions. And we have tremendous power over China. China can solve that problem with one meeting or one phone call.""WALL STREET REGULATION

column1: On breaking up big banks: ""The big banks aren't big banks compared to other big banks. In other words if you look at the big banks in Germany or if you look at the big banks in China
column2: I have the biggest bank in the world right downstairs four or five floors below us. ... If we make our big banks too much not big
column3: they won't be able to compete with the banks from China and the banks from Germany and other big banks.""On repealing Dodd-Frank: ""I'm going to be making a statement about this in approximately two weeks having to do with Dodd-Frank. Much of it is very bad. Much of it gives so much power to the regulators that the bankers are unable to function.""""Dodd Frank has made it impossible for bankers to function. ... It makes it very hard for bankers to loan money for people to create jobs
column4: for people with businesses to create jobs. And that has to stop. And will there be bad loans made? Yes
column5: but there are bad loans made now with Dodd-Frank
column6: OK
column7: I mean all you have to do is take a look.""""The rules and regulations of Dodd Frank have made it so impossible to carry out business and to
column8: especially with respect to lending to businesses who are going to employ a lot of people. So I'm going to make a statement about it. But Dodd-Frank - I mean there are some things in Dodd-Frank that can stay but overall Dodd-Frank has been very bad.""STOCK MARKET
column9: TECH INDUSTRY

column1: On tech stocks:""You have a stock market that is very strange. Could be a little bit similar to
column2: would you say it's nine years ago now? I guess it's sort of nine years ago. But you know
column3: you look at some of these tech stocks that are so
column4: so weak as a concept and a company and they're selling for so much money. And I would have said can that ever happen again? I think that could happen again.""""I'm talking about companies that have never made any money
column5: that have a bad concept and that are valued at billions of dollars. So here we go again.""

column1: FEDERAL RESERVE
On auditing the Fed: ""I think number one
column2: the Federal Reserve should be audited. You know
column3: they're not auditing it. And so far not too many people have been able to tell me why. I'm not one that says we should get rid of the Federal Reserve because I think the Federal Reserve has an important function
column4: but it should certainly be audited and ... we should at least watch what they're doing from the dollar standpoint.""On timing for audit-the-Fed legislation: ""It's not my highest priority. I have other priorities like rebuild our military. ... It's not my number one priority. But certainly it's one of the things that we'll be doing.""On replacing Fed Chair Janet Yellen: ""I'm not a person that thinks Janet Yellen is doing a bad job. I happen to be a low interest rate person
column5: unless inflation rears its ugly head
column6: which could happen at some point. It doesn't seem like it's happening any time soon. I don't think I want to at this point - I mean
column7: number one
column8: she's got time left.""""I would rather have a Republican in the position
column9: but I am not the enemy of Janet Yellen. ... Look
column10: if interest rates were raised and if the dollar went up more
column11: we'd be doing no business. We're being killed by other countries devaluing their currencies.""CLIMATE

column1: On the Paris accords:""Not a big fan. No. Not a big fan because other countries don't adhere to it and China doesn't adhere to it
column2: and China's spewing into the atmosphere.""""Take a look at China with certain agreements where they have to do it within 30 years
column3: and we have to do it almost immediately. You understand what I mean by that? The agreements are not fair agreements
column4: number one. And I would say that I will be looking at that very
column5: very seriously
column6: and at a minimum
column7: I will be renegotiating those agreements. At a minimum. Ok? And at a maximum
column8: I may do something else. But those agreements are one-sided agreements
column9: and they're bad for the United States.""CHINA

column1: On devaluation of the yuan:""China was in big trouble a year ago
column2: now all of a sudden they cut their currency. They're taking more business out of the United States. ... China
column3: whenever they have a problem
column4: they devalue their currency. And they take more money out of the United States. Jobs
column5: money
column6: product.""Trade:""We cannot allow China and other countries to rip the soul out of our country. And they will understand that.""South China Sea:

column1: They're building a massive fortress in the South China Sea. They're not supposed to be doing that."" RUSSIA
On Russian presence in Ukraine:""I don't like it. I don't like it at all.""On Russian President Vladimir Putin:""Putin made very nice statements about me. Very strong
column2: very nice statements. I think that's not a bad thing
column3: that's a good thing. I think I'll have a good relationship with Russia
column4: and I may not. And the fact that he's said good things about me doesn't mean that
column5: you know
column6: it's going to help him in a negotiation. It won't help him at all. And I'll know pretty soon in whether or not I'll have a good relationship with Russia. But wouldn't it be wonderful if we actually did have a good relationship with foreign countries as opposed to the way they're treating us now?""OBAMACARE

column1: Everyone knows. You know on Nov. 1
column2: they're going to announce new - the numbers are going to come out for Obamacare. They are going to be catastrophic.""""It's beyond terrible healthcare. And Obamacare in '17 collapses. Don't forget
column3: Obama pushed everything to '17 because he'll be out on the golf course. He'll be playing a nice round of golf someplace. Obamacare is part of the bubble problem. Now
column4: we're going to terminate Obamacare
column5: and we're going to replace it with something much better and much less expensive.""""Well
column6: the lines are very important. The lines meaning the state borders. These people are protected from competition. And you go to these states and they have - it's almost like a monopoly in many of the states. You have to get rid of the lines. And they almost did it with Obamacare. It almost worked out. ""ENTITLEMENT PROGRAMS

column1: I think that Medicaid should be sent to the states. Ok? Let them work it.""""It's very important that we protect Social Security and our Medicare without cuts. And I'm the only Republican that says that.""  BRITISH PRIME MINISTER DAVID CAMERON
I think he was inappropriate. I think he was totally inappropriate. He's got plenty of problems
